image.altText: A satellite image of a large black submarine on land surrounded by industrial buildings and cranes near the water.

items.synopsis: Until Australia's submarine fleet can go nuclear the navy must keep its near-retirement vessels deployable. It's been a struggle.

title.children: How Australia was left with only one deployable submarine

image.altText: a man walking next to an election poster of himself

items.synopsis: The Sydney MP makes formal complaints to police and the NSW anti-discrimination board and says he will launch defamation proceedings unless Mr Latham apologises.

title.children: Alex Greenwich takes legal action against Mark Latham over 'homophobic' tweet

image.altText: Heather Mitchell stands with two drinks in her hand in a room lit by a table lamp

items.synopsis: Actor Heather Mitchell's life has been as dramatic off screen as it has on. And she’s channelling those experiences into some of the greatest performances of her career.

title.children: How Heather Mitchell survived a 'testosterone, cocaine and alcohol-fuelled' workplace

image.altText: A worker smooths concrete at slab pour at building construction site at Radar Street at Lytton at Brisbane.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of infrastructure projects promised by the former federal government are not properly funded and may be cancelled if a major review deems they cannot be delivered.

title.children: Hundreds of 'completely underfunded' Coalition-era infrastructure projects on the chopping block

image.altText: An apartment block with large blackened area from fire caused by a missile attack and a crane hovering above

items.synopsis: Driving around Ukraine for the past two weeks revealed to me the extent of devastation that Vladimir Putin's war has wrought upon this country so rich in history, culture and potential, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Putin won't give up on Ukraine, but its people are filled with a deep, burning anger and won't surrender

image.altText: A composite image of Marion Scrymgour, Lidia Thorpe and Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

items.synopsis: The 2022 federal election delivered record results for First Nations representation in parliament. Ahead of the referendum, the ABC contacted the 11 politicians to hear directly from them what they think about a constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament.

title.children: There are 11 First Nations MPs and senators. Here's what they think of a Voice to Parliament

image.altText: Aerial view of a housing estate near Camden, NSW

items.synopsis: CoreLogic data shows Australian property prices have risen for the second consecutive month, suggesting a downturn in the housing market is coming to an end as interest rates stabilise.

title.children: House prices rise for second-straight month as interest rates appear to stabilise

image.altText: An African lady smiling in her new social housing residence

items.synopsis: The Parliamentary Budget Office warns phasing out property tax breaks may "trigger a significant economic shock". That's why next week's budget is more focused on increasing the supply of housing rather than trying to make housing affordable by reducing house prices.

title.children: Phasing out property tax breaks could save $74b but it also could create 'significant economic shock'

image.altText: a man in glasses sitting in front of a bookshelf

items.synopsis: The scrapping of the interest rate floor five years ago has led to "bad outcomes" for many Australians who secured ultra-cheap home loans during the pandemic and are now facing a fall over the mortgage cliff, says a former head of credit risk at the nation's financial regulator.

title.children: The lending boom is biting back against millions of Australians. Glenn's rules were meant to safeguard us

image.altText: An animation of Earth being orbited by hundreds of objects.

items.synopsis: For millennia humans have gazed up at the wonder of the night sky, but what we can see is rapidly changing because of our quest to be connected.

title.children: Earth's orbit is becoming more crowded and our window to the universe is at stake

image.altText: Woman in singlet top.

items.synopsis: The mother of Central Coast woman Leisl Smith who vanished in 2012 calls for laws to be amended to allow a verdict for the man who stood trial for her murder — but died — to be released.

title.children: Grieving mum pleads for trial verdict of daughter's murder accused to be unsealed

image.altText: An AFL executive speaks at a lectern.

items.synopsis: The AFL is set to name Andrew Dillon its next chief executive, taking over from Gillon McLachlan, who announced his upcoming resignation almost a year ago.

title.children: AFL names next chief executive almost a year after Gillon McLachlan's resignation

schema.headline: Andrew Dillon named AFL chief executive almost a year after Gillon McLachlan's resignation

liveBlogUpdate.headline: That's all from Andrew Dillon and Richard Goyder
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The AFL Commission chairman and AFL CEO-elect shake hands and bring the press conference to an end. Thanks for joining for the live portion, we'll have plenty more news and reaction to Dillon's appointment throughout the day at abc.net.au/sport .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'A truly national game': Dillon's pitch for the future
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "It's about being truly national. We have a truly national competition we want to be a truly national sport overseen by a truly national organisation. "We want to see AFL and AFLW and be financially robust and continue to grow. It's got to be a safe place. We want to be safe, culturally safe and also safe from a physical point of view. We will continue to put the health and safety of all our players and participants at the forefront."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'There's no boy's club here'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Andrew Dillon: "You only have to look at the calibre of our executive team and the calibre of my football integrity and legal team to say there's no boys club here. "We've got a talented diverse workforce and everyone's opinions are listened to and acted on. The more diverse the talent, the better decisions. I don't buy that one bit."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Will the grand final stay a day game?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Andrew Dillon stays on the fence. "I went to my first grand final in 1976. I've been to two drawn grand finals, I've been to a grand final at Waverly, and was fortunate enough over the last three years to go to a grand final that was at the Gabba at night. "I went to one at Optus Stadium, a twilight grand final and last year was back at the MCG for a day grand final. They've all been amazing. I haven't been to a bad grand final, but last year's was really good."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Why did this process take so long?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Richard Goyder responds: "The most important thing is the outcome of the outcome we announced today. It was towards the end of last year, we wanted to deal with the Hawthorn issue and as we've announced over the weekend, what governments have announced. "Hopefully we can move things forward over the next couple of days, a couple of things that have been the priority of the AFL which are incredibly important to the game so I don't think we've lost any I don't think we've lost any momentum over the period."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'Excitement, relief and trepidation': Dillon on hearing the news
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "It was a mixture of everything. It was excitement, relief and there was trepidation as well. "It's a massive job and a massive responsibility stop but to have Richard and the commission and trust me with that responsibility means a lot. "It was a mixture of everything, but right now I'm really excited. I'm just humbled proud to be here and have this great responsibility."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Dillon's extensive footy background
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "I have been so fortunate to be involved in footy at so many levels throughout my life from my first game as a five year old, right through the junior club and school football. "I umpired, albeit not very well, during my high school years and I played community football for 16 years at a senior level. "I am running an AusKick centre, assistant coach at senior level and coached junior girls' football for five years. I can tell you in my 23 years at the AFL there is been no tougher job than trying to run a training session on a Friday afternoon and under 13 girls team."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'A humbling moment': Dillon
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The new boss is speaking now. "It is a really humbling moment for me to be appointed as the next CEO of the AFL. "Football has been a defining part of my life. As it has for so many of our supporters, it is a privilege and honour to be given the opportunity to leave the AFL. I'm looking forward to working with the AFL team, our clubs, our players, our coaches and the wider industry to ensure our game continues to expand its reach."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Andrew Dillon will take over on October 2
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Richard Goyder confirms the new man's start date. "Andrew will immediately become CEO-elect and in accordance with good practice, and the need for a smooth transition. Gillon McLachlan has agreed to be CEO of AFL until the conclusion of the 2023 AFL premiership season."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Andrew Dillon is here
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: He is joined by AFL chairman Richard Goyder, who says Dillon was the "standout choice" among a competitive field. "He knows the football community, he knows our supporters, volunteers, participants, players and has a clear vision when he wants to take the game to more and more people."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Andrew Dillon is the AFL's new chief executive
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good morning. The AFL has this morning confirmed that Andrew Dillon will replace Gillon McLachlan as its chief executive. Dillon will front the media shortly, and updates will be live here.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Andrew Dillon named AFL chief executive almost a year after Gillon McLachlan's resignation

image.altText: A woman and man walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia's headquarters in Sydney.

items.synopsis: It's now entirely possible the Reserve Bank won't get inflation down to 2-3 per cent, regardless of whether it raises interest rates again. And it's extraordinary this scenario is not being more widely discussed, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Australia may be enduring 'sticky inflation' and interest rate rises are unlikely to solve the underlying problem

image.altText: a man with a bleeding mouth on a sports field

items.synopsis: A Sydney football club withdraws from its competition after a referee, who remains in hospital, was allegedly attacked by a spectator on Friday night.

title.children: Man charged over alleged assault of referee at football match in Sydney's south-west

image.altText: A woman's hands resting in her lap. She's wearing rings, bracelets and a watch

items.synopsis: Prisha's elderly neighbour had heard the commotion coming from her Brisbane home for months and decided to take action. The small act of kindness changed the migrant's life.

title.children: Prisha didn't realise she was suffering from domestic violence. To her, it was 'normal'

image.altText: A bright light is seen fired from a Navy ship.

items.synopsis: Militaries around the world are scrambling to realise the 'God mode' of invulnerability and infinite ammunition promised by laser weapons, writes Sean O'Byrne.

title.children: Can a laser really stop a tank? Here's how directed energy weapons work

image.altText: Kim Yo Jong, sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, delivers a speech during a national meeting in Pyongyang.

items.synopsis: The sister of North Korea's Kim Jong Un calls US President Joe Biden senile and miscalculating following his latest summit with South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol.

title.children: Kim Yo Jong rebukes US-South Korea summit and 'extreme' hostility toward Pyongyang

image.altText: A man stands against the window

items.synopsis: After a stroke in 2021, Richard Crookes travels to Adelaide every eight weeks for rehabilitation because he can’t get the treatment he needs in the Northern Territory.

title.children: Richard used to wrangle crocodiles in the Top End. Now he struggles to make a cup of tea

image.altText: Ukrainian service members from a 3rd separate assault brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

items.synopsis: The head of Russia's mercenary Wagner Group threatens to withdraw some of his troops from the eastern city of Bakhmut if Moscow does not send more ammunition.

title.children: Ukraine 'retains control' of key supply route into Bakhmut as Wagner Group boss threatens withdrawal

image.altText: A man walks by the ruins of a destroyed house, with wreckage spread across a street.

items.synopsis: The paramilitary Rapid Support Forces group offers to extend an apparent ceasefire for another three days as the army claims it has destroyed convoys moving towards Khartoum.

title.children: Sudan army, RSF trade blame as fighting continues through renewed ceasefire

image.altText: A composite image of three women dressed for a red carpet

items.synopsis: It's the first Monday in May and it's one of the most photographed events in the world. Here's what to expect from this year's Met Gala and where you can watch it.

title.children: It's the event that costs $50,000 for a ticket. Here's when the Met Gala is and who's expected to show

image.altText: Chess world champion Ding Liren sits in front of the logo of the logo for chess's world governing body.

items.synopsis: Ding Liren unseats Magnus Carlsen as world champion without playing the Norwegian five-time winner who chose not to defend the crown he claimed in 2021.

title.children: China's Ding Liren becomes chess world champion

image.altText: A rose is placed next to the sculpture of the walrus 'Freya' in Oslo.

items.synopsis: A bronze sculpture of Freya, a walrus that gained global attention last year by playfully basking in the Oslo fjord until officials euthanased her, has been unveiled in Norway.

title.children: Life-size sculpture of controversially euthanased walrus unveiled in Norway

image.altText: House bound for outback Queensland on the back of a truck

items.synopsis: As building a new home becomes more challenging and expensive in regional Queensland, many people are opting to have ready-built houses trucked in from thousands of kilometres away.

title.children: 'Home delivery' booming in outback towns as construction costs skyrocket

image.altText: Esteban Ocon enters the pits with people in the pit lane at Baku

items.synopsis: Sergio Perez has closed in on the lead in the Formula 1 drivers' championship with victory at the Azerbaijan Grand Prix before onlookers narrowly escaped injury after a pit lane mishap in Baku.

title.children: Motorsport governing body breaches international sporting code as F1 driver almost hits people in pit lane

image.altText: Woman stressed out with hand on forehead

items.synopsis: The latest TikTok wellness trend would have you believe high cortisol levels are to blame for weight gain, food cravings, fatigue and insomnia, but there's more to the story, write Theresa Larkin and Susan Thomas.

title.children: How the 'stress hormone' cortisol can affect your body

image.altText: View of Hobart Cityscape from Centotaph with cloud-covered Mount Wellinton backdrop

items.synopsis: After one quarter in the sun, Queensland has been knocked off the top of CommSec's State of the States economic rankings, and overtaken by the island state, which now leads on three key indicators.

title.children: Queensland loses best state economy crown to Tasmania

image.altText: Sydney FC A-League Women players celebrate with the championship trophy.

items.synopsis: After losing three consecutive grand finals, the Sky Blues come out on top of newcomers Western United with a comprehensive 4-0 triumph in the championship decider.

title.children: Sydney FC dominates Western United to clinch fourth A-League Women championship

image.altText: A choir of elderly people

items.synopsis: A music program that's "just like a party" is changing moods and improving the language skills of people with dementia.

title.children: Singing and music ignite neurons in the brain. Meet the people who say it's been life-changing

image.altText: a little boy in a cowboy hat leans on a fence watching a bullriding competition

items.synopsis: The small town of Hughenden — with its population of just over 1,000 residents — welcomes visitors from across the country seeking stunning views and outback hospitality.

title.children: Tiny town's population doubles with celebration of outback Queensland's vast horizons
